title-group.article-title: CORPORATE FINANCE IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES: AN ANALYSIS OF DIVIDEND POLICY AMONG PUBLICLY LISTED FIRMS IN JAMAICA

abstract.p: This paper adds to the emerging literature on corporate management practices in the Caribbean by undertaking a pioneering study of dividend policy among publicly listed firms in Jamaica. The paper finds that publicly firms in Jamaica pay dividends once their earnings permit such. Dividend omissions are always associated with declines in profitability and/or losses. Thus the emerging phenomenon of "disappearing dividends" which has been observed in a number of countries does not appear to apply to publicly listed firms in Jamaica, in fact all publicly listed firms in Jamaica can be classified as dividend payers. The study also finds that like many of their counterparts in other countries, publicly listed firms in Jamaica follow stable dividend policies and engage in dividend smoothing along the lines suggested by the Lintner (1956) model. The study undertakes a pooled time series analysis of dividend policy in Jamaica, which confirms the predictions of the Lintner model in the Jamaican context. The results provide further evidence of the robust nature of the Lintner model in explaining corporate dividend policy in a variety of macroeconomic environments and stock market microstructures, a true rarity in the financial economics literature.
